Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: 1 MHz, GaN-Based, Modular, Cascaded Z-Source Inverters for Scalable Grid-Interactive Photovoltaic (PV) Applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective is to research a new generation of grid-connected PV (photovoltaic) inverters to achieve high efficiency and MHz operation through a collaborative university-industry project. The approach is to apply wide band-gap power semiconductors in transformerless, cascaded, modular DC-AC inverters. We will develop an advanced control strategy that is capable of system-level fault monitoring and detection to maximize the PV output power, achieve reactive power compensation and to reduce the ground leakage current.

Intellectual Merits: This research leverages the recent technological advances in GaN power switching devices and looks beyond the conventional single DC bus inverter topology. The buck-boost function and shoot-through capability of the Z-source network in the proposed modular dc-ac inverter can enable the inverter to obtain high efficiency, high performance and high reliability operation at MHz system output switching frequencies. The proposed research offers opportunities to discover and invent new concepts in emerging power semiconductor devices and advanced converter topology/control in grid-connected PV systems.

Broader Impact: The proposed research will have a significant impact on PV inverter manufacturers by providing novel electronic power converters with increased conversion efficiency and increased reliability. Furthermore, this research will also impact the power semiconductor industry by addressing the cross-disciplinary challenges of the new generation of PV inverters. The research will be integrated into the power courses at FAMU-FSU College of Engineering to meet an increasing workforce and technology needs. Other education plans are to include student internships at the partner company, involve female and minority students in the research, provide outreach to high school students, and stimulate academia-industry interactions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this project is to develop high-efficient grid-tied PV inverters by taking advantages of commercial available GaN semiconductor devices and quasi-z-source inverter topology. In addition, the application of high performance Wide Band Gap (WBG) device changes the design of power electronics converter, which has been researched in this project. The main results from this project include: (1) A new PV system structure based on cascaded quasi-Z-source inverters (qZSI) utilizing eGaN devices. This new type of PV inverter is capable of achieving high efficiency and high power density. The developed 250W qZSI module can achieve 98.06% peak efficiency, which is around 1.5% improvement over commercial products. Moreover, the optimized design of proposed PV system has been derived. The design method can provide the optimal number of cascaded modules, switching frequency and passive component parameters for different selected PV panels; (2) Ground leakage current suppression method. Transformerless PV inverters including proposed qZSI can achieve high efficiency but face challenge to suppress the ground leakage current with extra cost and size penalty. This research not only provides a novel model to analyze the ground leakage current issues of proposed inverter but also develop two cost-effective solutions without size penalty; and (3) New control challenges analysis and solutions.  Since proposed qZSI with GaN can be operated with a much higher switching frequency, the control aspects demonstrate different features compared to Si-based inverters. For example, some operation state will only appear in high switching frequency operation leading to unexpected oscillation in inverter current and voltage, which requires to be damped by adding extra control mechanism. In addition, the output impedance characteristics of proposed inverter behaves differently compared to Si-based countparts, which affect system stability and the corresponding control design in a positive way. A new mathematical model considering these features has been developed and solutions based on this model have been verified in the laboratory. The proposed technologies have achieved high efficiency, high power density and high reliability of grid-tied PV inverter in several kW to 10 kW range, it helps to expedite the commercialization of module-integrated PV inverter in residential application. It also help promote the application of WBG device to PV inverters. This project is a close collaboration between university and industry. The circuit design, prototype building and control system development has been under constant guidance from PV inverter and GaN device manufactures, some students who have involved in this research also have conducted internship in the industry partners. This collaboration is not only beneficial for technology transfer, but also for creating a high quality integrated education, research and engineering for students to meet an increasing workforce and technology needs of the nation’s PV industry. The research results have been disseminated to the research society and community by paper, presentation, invited talk, seminar and open house.
